Posts.Content: As I posted last week I have had a prostatectomy (4th March) and was told that I would have to have a catheter in place for 3 weeks. When my appointment came through for a TWOC it was 3 weeks and 5 days later (should be removed today). On phoning the hospital for an admission time I was told they didn't have a bed for me and I now have to wait until Monday ... 4 weeks post surgery. I am already worried about the incontinence and want to begin the kegel exercises again. Is it going to make it worse by leaving the catheter in place for this long? Just about everything has gone wrong - keyhole surgery was abandoned and after 2 hours in theatre the surgeon had to resort to full open surgery, wound opened up after 12 days, urinary infection and now an extra week with catheter. Is anything going to be straightforward for me I wonder!
Posts.Title: can't get rid of this catheter

Posts.Content: Thanks for the positive comments folks, just what I needed. I've been feeling pretty sorry for myself - not like me at all and time I gave myself a kick in the butt. Going in today to have it removed then I'm sure I'll feel I'm on the way to recovery. Thanks again.
Posts.Title: can't get rid of this catheter

Posts.Content: Just had a trip to the Dr for a dressing change only to find out that I now have a urine infection. When will these problems end? It's just been one problem after another for the past 3 weeks.
Posts.Title: Post prostatectomy problems

Posts.Content: Hi, I've joined the forum in my hubbies name so that we can both access and ask questions of the people that have "been there, done that". Hubby had his prostatectomy on 4th March, discharged from hospital on 7th after the surgery didn't go to plan. It should have been keyhole but the surgeon said that the prostate was low and tucked behind the pubic bone so open surgery was needed. Anyway, 36 staples later he came home to recuperate. After 10 days the community nurse came out and removed all of the staples. Low and behold the wound opened up top to bottom. Restitching apparently is not an option so he was steristripped and dressings applied. Yesterday the nurse came out again to change dressings and take off some of the strips to find that the wound had opened again. She's packed it with some iodine strips and covered with a dressing again. In the meantime he also has to deal with a catheter which has already been in place for 20 days and not due to be removed until next Friday - another 6 days time. We have also had a catheter malfunction in the middle of the night and found the bed absolutely drenched because the tube had come apart at the junction - not unheard of apparently in the see through tubes. We now put micropore around the junctions to ensure that doesn't happen again. It's all been very stressful and with the wound business it's beginning to affect hubbies state of mind and I am seriously worried that he may fall into a depression. Has anyone else had these type of problems? It would be good to know that there is a light at the end of the tunnel. Oh, also the surgeon phoned and told him to expect to be VERY wet. He is feeling the urge to urinate and we wonder if that's a good sign? He also had a semi-erection in the middle of the night a couple of nights ago. Not good with a catheter in situ. Are there any similar stories? Any advice please?
Posts.Title: Post prostatectomy problems

Posts.Content: Yes, it certainly seems to be two steps forward and one back. Sarg we are in UK and care is under the NHS. I don't think it's unusual for the community nurse to remove staples/stitches and dress wounds at home although any future care will now be with his GP. He has to go to the medical centre on Monday to have his dressing changed as the nurse told him on her last visit to our home that as he can move around she wont be out again. Not sure but I think you only get so many home visits then you go back to the GP. We've been checking the dressing regularly today. There seems to be some leakage staining through although he says there is no pain, tenderness or heat from the surrounding skin. It's just awful to go through the trauma of a major op to then have the worry of something totally unexpected. We're both looking forward to the catheter being removed next Friday. Just hoping that nothing else goes wrong. Thanks for your good wishes.
Posts.Title: Post prostatectomy problems

Posts.Content: Just had a trip to the Dr for a dressing change only to find out that I now have a urine infection. When will these problems end? It's just been one problem after another for the past 3 weeks.
Posts.Title: Post prostatectomy problems

Posts.Content: Thanks for all of your comments. His op wasn't robotic newporter. It was manual keyhole surgery but the surgeon had to convert to full open surgery due to "lack of vision". The surgeon called to say that the results from pathology are good and they have removed 100% of the tumor. I know I should be jumping for joy but at the moment I'm thinking suppose they're wrong and suppose something else goes wrong!! Before surgery Hubs was doing his Kegel exercises regularly but obviously with the catheter still in he has been unable to continue since the beginning of the month. Are all prostatectomy's carried out robotically in USA?? Here in UK we only have 2 hospitals with that facility (that we could have been referred to anyway but miles and miles away from where we live). Perhaps I should mention that my husband is 57 and had a Gleason of 7 (4 + 3).

Posts.Title: Post prostatectomy problems

Posts.Content: Hi mkane, glad I'm not alone in the "bad experience" club!! What's your story? Being in UK my op was carried out under the NHS so no choice of surgeons although my surgeon is highly respected as a specialist in the field. It looks like your PSA test results are all over the place!!
Posts.Title: just dribbling

Posts.Content: I haven't been on here for some time and just thought I would post an update on my condition. Basically I've had a hell of a time since my prostatectomy. If you've read previous threads you'll know that I've suffered with wound opening, catheter in for just over 4 weeks, infections and very slow to pass urine. Well the list goes on ... I have had constant infections, catheter back in for a further 2 weeks, severe strictures which prevent urine flow completely culminating in a 2 night hospial stay last week after the district nurse attempted to insert 3 different sized catheters at home with no luck then the nurse at hospital tried 2 more and called the doctor who also had a go!!! Between them they must have nudged something and I began to drip (literally) urine which relieved the pressure. I am now booked in for another operation in 2 weeks time to hopefully sort the problem out. I'm just keeping my fingers crossed because I can't go on like this. I am pleased for most of you on this site who have had a prostatectomy as it seems the vast majority come through unscathed but let my story be a warning to anyone weighing up the pro's and cons of surgery. We don't all come through recovery text book style and there ARE problems and related health issues to be aware of.
Posts.Title: just dribbling

Posts.Content: I am so sorry. My journey has been nothing so far compared to yours. Here in the UK there is a huge push towards prostate cancer awareness, too many men are too ignorant or embarassed about the prostate examination. Let's hope and pray that a cure for cancer will be found. All the best mate.
Posts.Title: just dribbling

Posts.Content: Hi, I had my prostatectomy 4th March and have had various problems since then - most of which have thankfully sorted themselves out, but I am still having problems peeing. I am only able to dribble when I pee. My bladder feels full but the flow is painfully slow. It can take up to 5 minutes to empty. Does anyone else have this problem? I have an apt to see my consultant on 8th May and have seen my GP several times over the past few weeks but he's not a great help ... hasn't once examined me, just pushes pills. Any advice?
Posts.Title: just dribbling

Posts.Content: Yes I agree with newporter, it sounds like it could be either infection or urethral stricture. I sincerely hope it's infection. I had my prostatectomy 3 months ago and have been plagued with strictures. If this is what it is you will have increased urge to urinate, flow will be restricted, gradually decreasing and it will be painful to pass. I have been dilated once, had several catheters, been taught self dilation and still get a stricture once every 2 weeks. I am now waiting for further surgery so my fingers are crossed that a course of antibiotics will relieve your symptoms!
Posts.Title: Bladder spasms, frequent strong urges to urinate how can I get past this issue.

Posts.Content: Yes it's me again folks and another problem seems to be rearing it's head. I am writing on behalf of my husband who had his prostatectomy almost 6 weeks ago. Catheter was removed 2 weeks ago and since then he has been getting up to pee anything between 6 and 12 times [U]a night[U] I have done a little research on the internet but find that people complain if they are up 4 times a night . He has an infection which he is taking antibiotics for but he had this problem before he started taking them and it is continuing and not getting any better. Are we expecting too much? Is 6 to 12 times excessive at this stage? Other than that he does not leak at all which is good but the lack of sleep can't be good for him??
Posts.Title: Night time urination
